questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following tumors is best suited to study the mechanism of multi-step 
carcinogenesis?
questions.explanation:
Multi-step carcinogenesis is best studied in colon carcinoma. The molecular model for the evolution of colorectal cancers is described as 
Fearon-Vogelstein adenoma-carcinoma sequence.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following procarcinogens does not require metabolic activation?
questions.explanation:
Cyclophosphamide is a directly-acting carcinogen that does not require metabolic activation. Carcinogens can be direct-acting or indirect-acting based on their activation. Direct-acting carcinogens require no metabolic conversion to become carcinogenic. Most are weak 
carcinogens, but some are important because they are cancer chemotherapeutic drugs (e.g., 245 
Sold by @itachibot alkylating agents). The direct-acting carcinogens include: • Alkylating Agents: •  -Propiolactone • Dimethyl sulfate • Diepoxybutane • Anticancer drugs (cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, nitrosoureas, and others) • Acylating Agents: • 1-Acetyl-imidazole • Dimethylcarbamyl chloride Indirect-acting carcinogens (procarcinogens) are chemicals that require metabolic conversion to 
become active carcinogens. The carcinogenic product of metabolism is called an ultimate 
carcinogen. The indirect-acting carcinogens include: • Polycyclic and heterocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons: • Benz[a]anthracene • Benzo[a]pyrene • Dibenz[a,h]anthracene • 3-Methylcholanthrene • 7,12-Dimethylbenz[a]anthracene • Aromatic amines, amides, azo dyes: • 2-Naphthylamine ( -naphthylamine) • Benzidine • 2-Acetylaminofluorene • Dimethylaminoazobenzene (butter yellow) • Natural plant and microbial products: • Aflatoxin B1 • Griseofulvin • Cycasin • Safrole • Betel nuts • Others • Nitrosamine and amides • Vinyl chloride, nickel, chromium • Insecticides, fungicides • Polychlorinated biphenyls 246 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A 45-year-old man presents with a hyperpigmented lesion on his face. He is a farmer by 
occupation and works for long hours with sun exposure. He is at increased risk for all of the 
following except:
questions.explanation:
Seborrheic keratosis is not associated with exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sun exposure. UV rays derived from sun exposure are associated with the increased incidence of: • Squamous cell carcinoma • Basal cell carcinoma • Melanoma of the skin Actinic keratosis is a precancerous skin condition that can cause squamous cell cancer if 
untreated.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which form of radiation is responsible for cutaneous cancer? 236 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
UVB (ultraviolet B) causes cutaneous cancers due to the formation of pyrimidine dimers in DNA. When DNA absorbs energy from UVB, there is a covalent crosslinking of pyrimidine bases and 
distortion of the DNA helix. This prevents proper pairing of the dimer with bases in the opposite 
DNA strand. Normally, these defects are repaired by nucleotide excision repair pathway. Defects in nucleotide 
excision repair pathway result in xeroderma pigmentosum. UV portion of the solar spectrum is divided into three wavelength ranges: Note: UVC is the most potent mutagen but is not considered significant as it is filtered out by the 
ozone layer. Spect 
rum Wavele 
ngth UVA 
320-40 
0 nm UVB 
280-32 
0 nm UVC 
200-28 
0 nm

questions.question:
Question 5: Individuals with repeated exposure to ionizing radiation are at increased risk of which of the 
following malignancies?
questions.explanation:
Individuals with repeated exposure to ionizing radiation are at increased risk of myeloid leukemia. Carcinogenic radiations include: • Electromagnetic radiation - 247 
Sold by @itachibot • ›-rays •  rays • Particulate radiation - •  particles •  particles • Protons • Neutrons Cancers due to ionizing radiation: • Most frequent - myeloid leukemia and thyroid cancer • Intermediate frequency - cancers of breast, lungs, and salivary glands • Relatively resistant cancers - cancers of skin, bone, and gastrointestinal tract

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following tumors is not caused by microbes?
questions.explanation:
Adenocarcinoma carcinoma of the lung is not associated with microbial etiopathogenesis. It is 
associated with smoking and genetic predispositions.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following malignancies is caused by HTLV-1?
questions.explanation:
Human T-cell leukemia-lymphoma virus (HTLV-1) causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma 
(ATLL). HTLV-1 encodes the viral protein Tax, which leads to polyclonal expansion of T cells. It exhibits 
tropism for CD4+ T cells. Human infection requires transmission of infected T cells through sexual intercourse, blood 
products or breast feeding. Leukemia develops only in 3-5% of infected individuals, typically after 
a long latent period of 40-60 years.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following pairs of HPV oncoproteins and target genes are correctly matched? 237 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The target genes for viral oncoproteins of human papilloma virus (HPV) are as follows: • E6 - p53 • E7 - RB The image given below shows the functions of the E6 and E7 oncoproteins of HPV. 248 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A 13-year-old child presents to the OPD with fever, pharyngitis, and cervical 
lymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear showed a predominance of lymphocytes. The heterophile 
agglutination test is positive. The causative organism of this condition is not implicated in 
which of the following tumors?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus. This 
virus is not implicated in follicular lymphoma. Epstein–Barr virus (EBV), a member of the herpesvirus family, has been implicated in: • African form of Burkitt lymphoma • B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed • A subset of Hodgkin lymphoma • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma • Gastric carcinoma - most common EBV associated malignancy • T-cell lymphoma and natural killer (NK) cell lymphoma

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements about Epstein-Barr virus is incorrect?

options.a: EBV infection always results in Burkitt lymphoma
options.b: It uses the complement receptor CD21 to attach and infect B cells
options.c: It is implicated in B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed people
options.d: It is a potent inducer of B-cell growth and transformation

questions.explanation:
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection does not always result in Burkitt lymphoma. EBV infection is highly prevalent even in areas where Burkitt lymphoma is not found. It 
commonly causes infectious mononucleosis. EBV uses the complement receptor CD21 to attach to and infect B cells. EBV genome 
triggers B-cell signaling pathways inducing B-cell growth and transformation. The infection of B cells is latent as there is no viral replication and the cells are not 
killed. However, B cells latently infected with EBV express viral proteins that result in the ability 
to propagate indefinitely in vitro. In the absence of T-cell immunity, EBV-infected B cells can 
rapidly grow out as aggressive B-cell tumors. 249 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following pathogens is implicated in the causation of primary effusion 
lymphoma and Castleman disease?
questions.explanation:
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) is a gamma-herpesvirus associated with Kaposi sarcoma, 
multicentric Castleman disease, and primary effusion lymphoma. They are lymphoproliferative diseases that are most commonly observed in immunocompromised 
individuals. The viral genome expresses genes responsible for inhibition of apoptosis, cell cycle 
entry, and angiogenesis.

questions.question:
Question 12: 238 
Sold by @itachibot A patient presents with abdominal distension and intermittent fever. Peripheral smear 
findings are normal. A tumor is resected and the histopathology image of the resected lymph 
node is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological image showing follicular hyperplasia of lymph 
nodes are suggestive of Castleman disease. Castleman disease (angiofollicular lymph node hyperplasia) is a lymphoproliferative disorder that 
can be associated with HHV-8 (multicentric Castleman disease or MCD) or idiopathic (unicentric 
Castleman disease or UCD) There are 3 major histological subtypes: • Hypervascular (UCD) - • Lollipop appearance - atrophic germinal centers with radially penetrating blood vessels • Onion skin appearance of mantle zone around germinal centers • Plasma cell subtype (UCD or MCD) - hypertrophic germinal centers, increased vascularity • Mixed variant (MCD) - mix of hypervascular and plasma cell subtype features in the same lymph 
node The clinical features include: • Multiple enlarged lymph nodes • Night sweats • Weight loss • Weakness and fatigue • Hepatosplenomegaly As this condition is associated with elevated levels of IL-6, the treatment involves IL-6 inhibitors 
like siltuximab and tocilizumab. Note: Hodgkin's lymphoma has characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells in the histopathological 
section of lymph nodes.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following is an EBV oncogene behaving like a constitutively active CD40 
receptor?
questions.explanation:
250 
Sold by @itachibot LMP-1 is an EBV oncogene that behaves like a constitutively active CD40 receptor. The CD40 receptor-like activity stimulates B-cell growth. LMP-1 activates the NF-B and JAK / 
STAT signaling pathways and promotes B-cell survival. It also prevents apoptosis by activating 
BCL2.

questions.question: Question 14: Helicobacter pylori increases the risk of development of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Helicobacter pylori is implicated in the following conditions: • Peptic ulcer • Gastric adenocarcinoma - preceded by chronic gastritis, gastric atrophy, intestinal metaplasia, 
and dysplasia • MALT lymphoma of the stomach - through polyclonal B cell proliferation Helicobacter pylori is protective for: • Barrett's esophagus • Adenocarcinoma of esophagus

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is the most common endocrinopathy caused by tumors?
questions.explanation:
Cushing syndrome is the most common endocrinopathy caused by tumors. Endocrinopathy refers to ectopic hormone production by non-endocrine tumors. Approximately, 
50% of the individuals with Cushing syndrome as endocrinopathy have carcinoma of the lung, 
chiefly the small-cell type. Hypercalcemia is the most common paraneoplastic syndrome. Cancer-associated hypercalcemia 
occurs due to: • Osteolysis induced by cancer - due to primary or secondary involvement of the skeleton by 
tumor • Production of calcemic humoral substances by extraosseous neoplasms - for example, 
parathyroid hormone-related protein. Only this mechanism is considered to be paraneoplastic.

questions.question:
Question 16: Patients with which of the following tumors present with pure red cell aplasia as a 
paraneoplastic manifestation?
questions.explanation:
Thymoma often presents with pure red cell aplasia as a paraneoplastic manifestation. Thymomas are unusual neoplasms of thymic epithelial tissue, ranging from small indolent tumors 
to aggressive thymic carcinomas. Pure red cell aplasia is a rare cause of anemia, caused by the absence of RBC precursors in the 
bone marrow. Causes of pure red cell aplasia include: • Neoplasms - thymomas and large granular lymphocytic leukemia 251 
Sold by @itachibot • Drug exposure - phenytoin, azathioprine, and isoniazid • Auto-immune disorders - neutralizing antibodies against erythropoietin • Parvovirus infection • Hereditary - Diamond Blackfan syndrome

questions.question:
Question 17: Which subtype of acute myeloid leukemia presents with disseminated intravascular 
coagulation as a paraneoplastic manifestation?
questions.explanation:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) as a paraneoplastic syndrome is most commonly 
associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) and prostatic adenocarcinoma. Major determinants of coagulopathy in APL are endogenous factors of the malignant leukemic 
cells and their interaction with host defense mechanisms. Factors that cause coagulopathy include: • Increased expression of procoagulant activity (PCA) • Expression of fibrinolytic and proteolytic properties • Secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines - interleukin-1b (IL-1b) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)

questions.question:
Question 18: A 60-year-old patient presents with loss of weight and appetite. On clinical examination, 
grade IV clubbing is evident. Imaging shows periosteal new bone formation and synovial 
effusion. Which of the following tumors is associated with this condition? 240 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history is suggestive of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. It is commonly 
associated with bronchiogenic carcinoma. Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is characterised by the following: • Periosteal new bone formation, primarily at the distal ends of long bones, metatarsals, 
metacarpals, and proximal phalanges • Arthritis of the adjacent joints • Clubbing of the digits

questions.question:
Question 19: A 55-year-old patient presents with generalized tiredness, malaise, muscle weakness, and 
bone pain. Laboratory investigations reveal serum calcium to be 13 mg/dL. Which of the 
following is lung cancers is implicated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and laboratory investigations are suggestive of hypercalcemia. It is 
associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. Tumors associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia: • Breast carcinoma • Lung carcinoma • Renal cell carcinoma • Ovarian carcinoma 252 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following paraneoplastic manifestations is likely to occur in a patient with a 
phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor?
questions.explanation: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor presents with osteomalacia as a paraneoplastic manifestation. Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor is caused due to mutation of the FGF-23 gene.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 48-year-old obese female presents with skin changes in her axilla and neck as shown in the 
image. Which of the following tumors is not associated with this condition? 241 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of acanthosis nigricans. It is not associated with thymoma. Acanthosis nigricans is a disorder characterized by gray-black patches of thickened, 
hyperkeratotic skin with a velvety appearance. The causal mechanism is immunologic due to 
secretion of epidermal growth factor. Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with: • Gastric carcinoma • Lung carcinoma • Gynecological cancers • Breast carcinoma • Bladder carcinoma • Gallbladder and bile-duct carcinoma • Acromegaly and gigantism • Dermatomyositis • Diabetes • Hashimoto thyroiditis • Lupus erythematosus • Phenylketonuria • Polycystic ovary syndrome • Systemic sclerosis • Wilson syndrome

questions.question:
Question 22: A 45-year-old patient presents with headache, vertigo, tinnitus, and visual disturbance. On 
further evaluation, blood hemoglobin and hematocrit levels are found to be 18 g/dL and 62% 
respectively. Which of the following tumors does not present with these paraneoplastic 
manifestations?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and laboratory investigations are suggestive of polycythemia which is 
not seen in melanoma as a paraneoplastic manifestation. Polycythemia, as a paraneoplastic syndrome, is mediated by erythropoietin (EPO). EPO is a 
glycoprotein that induces differentiation of erythrocyte colony-forming units in the bone marrow 253 
Sold by @itachibot to promote red blood cell production. Under normal physiological conditions, EPO is produced by peritubular renal interstitial cells in 
response to local tissue hypoxia. However, in tumors, EPO production occurs in the neoplastic 
cells themselves.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of these paraneoplastic syndromes is associated with small-cell carcinoma lung?
questions.explanation:
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) is associated with small cell carcinoma 
of lung.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 60-year-old patient notices spontaneously appearing and disappearing painful, linearly 
arranged nodules in different parts of the body. Which of the following malignancies is not 
associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) 
and it is not associated with bladder carcinoma. Trousseau syndrome may be encountered in association with deep-seated cancers, most often 
carcinomas of the pancreas or lung. It is caused by hypercoagulability leading to multiple repeated 
venous thromboembolism. Malignant brain tumors, hematological malignancies, and adenocarcinomas of the pancreas, 
stomach, ovary, uterus, lungs, and kidneys are at the highest risk of venous thromboembolism 
(VTE) development. Advanced, metastatic cancer has been shown to be associated with an increased risk of VTE 
compared with localized tumors.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 24-year-old patient with paroxysmal hypertension is suspected to have malignant 
pheochromocytoma. Which of the following tumor markers will help you confirm your 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The serum levels of catecholamines are elevated in malignant pheochromocytoma. Extra-adrenal 
location is the only criteria for malignancy in pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytoma is a rare catecholamine-secreting tumor that may precipitate life-threatening 
hypertension. It is classically associated with three syndromes: • von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2) • Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) Catecholamines produced by pheochromocytomas are metabolized within chromaffin cells. 
Norepinephrine is metabolized to normetanephrine, and epinephrine is metabolized to 
metanephrine. Because this process occurs within the tumor, independent of catecholamine 
release, pheochromocytomas are best diagnosed by the measurement of these metabolites, rather 
than by measurement of the parent catecholamines. 254 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following are oncofetal antigens?
questions.explanation:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are oncofetal antigens. Alpha-fetoprotein is a valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of the 
following tumors: • Primary hepatocellular carcinoma • Hepatoblastoma • Non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors • Embryonal carcinoma • Teratomas • Choriocarcinoma • Yolk sac carcinoma • Germ cell tumors of the ovary and extragonadal germ cell tumors Regenerated hepatic tissue following liver damage due to viral hepatitis, chemically induced 
necrosis, and liver surgery are associated with moderately raised serum AFP levels. Carcinoembryonic antigen is normally detected in glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells. It is useful in 
detection, assessing recurrence, and prognosis of the following tumors: • Adenocarcinoma of lung • Colorectal carcinoma CEA levels >5 ng/dL are noted in ascites fluid associated with malignancy. Canalicular pattern 
for polyclonal CEA more sensitive for hepatocellular carcinoma, metastases in pancreatic 
adenocarcinoma and not sensitive for metastasis in bile duct adenoma. Elevated levels are also present in the following non-neoplastic conditions: • Cirrhosis • Biliary obstruction • Hepatitis • Inflammatory bowel disease • Smokers • Post-surgical bowel sequestration • Mucocele • Benign cysts may be positive for carcinoembryonic antigen

questions.question:
Question 27: A 42-year-old patient is diagnosed with breast cancer. Which of the following glycoproteins is 
expected to be elevated in this patient? 243 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The level of cancer antigen 15-3 (CA 15-3) is elevated in patients with breast cancer. 255 
Sold by @itachibot The reference range of serum CA 15-3 is less than 30 U/mL. It is used to monitor response to 
breast cancer treatment and disease recurrence.

questions.question:
Question 28: A 51-year-old male patient who is a chronic smoker presents with dry persistent cough and 
progressive dyspnea. You are suspecting small cell carcinoma of lung. Which of the following 
tumor markers is likely to be elevated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of small cell carcinoma of the lung (SCLC) in which levels 
of neuron-specific enolase (NSE) are elevated. NSE is also called gamma enolase or enolase 2 (ENO2) and is encoded by ENO2 gene. It is a 
phosphopyruvate hydratase that is produced by small-cell lung carcinomas, which are 
neuroendocrine in origin. Their levels have been implicated as a prognostic factor for patients 
with small-cell lung cancer.

questions.question: Question 29: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.explanation:
NRG-1 (Neuregulin-1) is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). GIST are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, the stomach being the most 
common site. They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells of the GIT. GIST is 
seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life and has an equal preponderance among males and females. 
Most patients present with haematemesis, melena, or vague abdominal pain. The most common 
indications for surgery include bleeding and obstruction. The GIST may occur in a sporadic form or as part of familial syndromes. In sporadic GIST, the 
most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRA 
mutation (8%). Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells or plumper epithelioid cells, or a 
mixed pattern. The below image shows the microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of 
spindle-shaped tumor cells. 256 
Sold by @itachibot Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient GIST is a subset of wild-type GIST seen with Carney 
triad or Carney-Stratakis syndrome. Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. Succinate dehydrogenase 
(SDH) - deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be used 
instead. During surgical resection of GIST, care must be taken to prevent capsule rupture, which causes 
seeding of nearby tissues leading to relapse in 100% of the cases. If capsule rupture occurs, 
adjuvant therapy with imatinib is indicated regardless of tumor extent. Other options: Option A: KIT (CD117): This is the most well-known marker for GISTs. About 85% of GISTs show 
mutations in the KIT gene, leading to the expression of the KIT protein on the cell surface. KIT is 
a receptor tyrosine kinase, and its activation is a key driver in the pathogenesis of GISTs. Option B: SDH (Succinate Dehydrogenase): SDH mutations are associated with a subset of GISTs, 
particularly those that are KIT and PDGFRA wild-type. Loss of SDH function is characteristic of 
this subgroup, and SDH deficiency can be demonstrated through immunohistochemistry. Option C: PDGFRA (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor Alpha): Mutations in the PDGFRA 
gene account for approximately 5-10% of GISTs. Similar to KIT, PDGFRA is a receptor tyrosine 
kinase, and mutations in this gene can lead to the development of GISTs. 257 
Sold by @itachibot Components of Immune System
